channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Burkina Faso, Violent Protests Against Plan to Extend Leader’s Rule
item.description: Demonstrators in Ouagadougou set fire to the Parliament building, took over state broadcasters and torched the homes of the president’s relatives.
item.dc:creator: By HERVÉ TAOKO and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Malala Yousafzai Donates Prize Money to Rebuild Gaza School
item.description: The Pakistani teenager who shared the Nobel Peace Prize this year donated $50,000 from another award to rebuild a United Nations school damaged in the war between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Taiwanese Tycoon Faces Charges in Cooking Oil Scandal
item.description: Wei Ying-chung is the highest-profile person to face prosecution over revelations that have raised questions about the safety of Taiwan’s domestic and exported food supply.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Protesters in New Taipei City, Taiwan, holding signs calling for a boycott of Ting Hsin, a company accused of selling substandard cooking oil made from materials intended for animal feed.

item.title: Chinese and South Korean Students Face Fallout From Suspicions of SAT Cheating
item.description: The Educational Testing Service, which administers the test worldwide, is withholding the scores of those who took it on Oct. 11 while the company investigates the allegations.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Israel Blocks Access to Contested Holy Site in Jerusalem
item.description: Authorities closed off all access to a holy site in the Old City on Thursday, a step that a Palestinian spokesman called “a declaration of war.”
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: A Palestinian woman gestured toward an Israeli police officer in the Old City of Jerusalem on Thursday.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Supplanting the Symbols of Warfare
item.description: With the relentless spread of conflicts of faith and identity, the emblems of conventional warfare have changed.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Protesters Storm Burkina Faso Parliament, Set Fire
item.description: Protesters stormed Burkina Faso's parliament Thursday, dragging furniture and computers onto the street and setting the main chamber ablaze, forcing the government to cancel a vote to allow the president to seek another term next year.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Larry Diamond on Political Change in Hong Kong
item.description: Larry Diamond, a political sociologist, discussed the prospects for political liberalization in Hong Kong and the Chinese mainland in light of the pro-democracy demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: By QITONG CAO

item.title: SodaStream to Close Factory in West Bank
item.description: The producer of home carbonation systems, which became a focal point of a movement to boycott Israeli products made in the West Bank, said it planned to close the facility next year.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Sweden Recognizes Palestinian State
item.description: Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman of Israel said the decision by Stockholm was unfortunate and would strengthen radical elements and Palestinian recalcitrance.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Don’t Let Ebola Dehumanize Africa
item.description: Fear-mongering about the disease is threatening to reverse decades of progress for the continent's image.
item.dc:creator: By ANGELIQUE KIDJO

item.title: Letter From India: Modi Fails, So Far, to Return Illicit Funds to India
item.description: The prime minister has vowed to bring back money that corrupt Indians have allegedly sent overseas. But his initial findings were disappointing.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH

item.title: Provocateur’s Death Haunts the Dutch
item.description: Ten years after the filmmaker Theo van Gogh was murdered by a Dutch Muslim, the Netherlands is still confronting challenges to the country’s values of tolerance and free expression.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: A portrait of Theo van Gogh painted in Amsterdam following his murder in 2004.

item.title: South Korean Court Orders Japanese Firm Nachi-Fujikoshi to Pay Forced Laborers
item.description: The company must give $75,800 to $94,800 to over a dozen people who were made to work in its factory during Japanese colonial rule of Korea.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Western Observer Finds Himself a Player in Hong Kong’s Protest Drama
item.description: Pro-Beijing newspapers in Hong Kong have made a former American intelligence officer a prime example in their allegations of a foreign conspiracy behind the city’s political tumult.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Beijing newspapers and politicians in Hong Kong have made Dan Garrett, center, a prime exhibit in their allegations of a Western conspiracy behind the city's political tumult.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Hamburger Face for Congress
item.description: This is what a normal campaign season looks like: strange people, funny memes, a strong influence of religion and lots of turnarounds.
item.dc:creator: By VANESSA BARBARA

item.title: France Denies It Agreed to Deliver Mistral-Class Warship to Russia
item.description: The government rejected claims that it would hand over the first of two vessels in November, saying conditions in Ukraine had not been met.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Sri Lanka Landslide’s Toll Is Lower Than Previously Thought, Officials Say
item.description: Three bodies, not six, were said to have been recovered, and 192 people, not 300, were believed to be missing.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Toronto School District Cancels Plans for Confucius Institute
item.description: Canada’s largest school district moved to terminate its agreement with the institute, which would have offered after-school Chinese language and culture classes, over concerns about China’s human rights record and restrictions on academic freedom.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: In early 2011, Hu Jintao, left, who was president of China at the time, visited a Confucius Institute at Walter Payton College Preparatory High School in Chicago. The program has entered partnerships with hundreds of schools and universities around the world.

item.title: Secularist Win Is Confirmed in Tunisia
item.description: The results were a blow for the Islamists who swept to power in the 2011 elections after the revolution that overthrew the government of President Zine el-Abdine Ben Ali.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Memo From Ukraine: After Ukraine Vote, a New Test: Burying a Legacy of Dysfunctional Politics
item.description: Dysfunction between presidents and prime ministers has hobbled the country, leaving it one of the poorest on the European Continent and often beholden to the whims of Russia.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine, second from left, and Prime Minister Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, third from left, at a wreath-laying ceremony last month for victims of a Nazi massacre.

item.title: Troops to Be Checked for Chemical Exposure in Iraq
item.description: A Pentagon review comes in response to an investigation by The New York Times of how troops who were exposed to nerve and mustard agents were treated by the military.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: Jeremiah Foxwell, a former naval petty officer who has been granted a partial medical disability for respiratory problems and is under consideration for a Purple Heart.

item.title: Memo From Ukraine: After Vote, a New Test: Burying a Legacy of Dysfunctional Politics
item.description: Dysfunction between presidents and prime ministers has hobbled the country, leaving it one of the poorest on the European Continent and often beholden to the whims of Russia.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine, second from left, and Prime Minister Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, third from left, at a wreath-laying ceremony last month for victims of a Nazi massacre.

item.title: Activist in Israel Is Wounded in Shooting
item.description: The victim, Yehuda Glick, advocates more Jewish access at a hotly contested holy site revered by Muslims and Jews.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Yehuda Glick in Jerusalem on Wednesday, just before he was wounded during a shooting.

item.title: Egypt Flattens Neighborhoods to Create a Buffer With Gaza
item.description: Demolition began a day after hundreds of homes were evacuated, making room for a buffer zone that officials say will stop militants and weapons.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MERNA THOMAS
item.media:description: Egyptian security forces demolished buildings in Rafah on Wednesday near the border with the southern Gaza Strip.
